WRITING.TEXT:
The spectrum is typically limited to democratic developed countries because they're comparable. At that comparison, the US is probably the farthest right on the spectrum, if not close. Sometimes it's defined by OECD countries in specific, in which the US is still one of the farthest right countries (but OECD includes a couple countries that aren't particuarly comparable, like Mexico and Turkey). By Gini for example, the US is the [third highest](http://www.oecd.org/social/income-distribution-database.htm) out of 36 countries. Only countries higher are Chile and Mexico (not a perfect measure of how left vs right wing a country is by any means though).
It depends on how you define big government. The American definition of "big government" would be a moderate size government at best by almost any comparable standard. Europe and Canada even are simply on a different scale. By European standards, both parties want very small governments in America. I personally think the US should have at least one European-style option for a party, but currently they do not.
What you're underestimating is how massive one modern wind turbine is. These things are well over 300 feet tall.

I don't think this shows anything about his concern being empty. There is absolutely nothing to see here in my opinion.
I think there is a big difference between MPs sexually harassing female MPs (where he did take action) and an inconsiderate joke made in private. The MP probably didn't even think this through, it was an side comment he thought would get some laughs.
There has to be a line where the party leader is not cracking the whip at every whim. Save reprimands for serious incidents that warrant serious action. He isn't reinforcing his point just by punishing a stupid joke.
I really think the only people with any interest in this are people that were already looking for a reason to criticize Trudeau. There are plenty of legitimate reasons to critisize Trudeau. This is not one of them unless.

She said he ran up to her afterwards and said he had just meant it as a joke, and he didn't mean to offend her.
It was a little inconsiderate, but holy shit do people love to take things way out of proportion. Have we all gotten so touchy that one ill considered joke is now a full blown controversy?
He should say "Sorry, it was a joke in poor taste" to her. That's it. No need to reprimand him. No need to make a huge deal out of this. Literally not even worth the journalists time to write this article.
I think its because of the youth slant, as you can see over 80% of people are 34 or below. Young people tend to lean left.

The cat on the bottom is suffocating and the top cat is just slightly annoyed he isn't being a good couch.
Such typical cat behaviour.
In a global democratic scale, it might be realistic. In an American scale, she was center-left probably.

Seriously, its the sad truth.
Yes; tomorrow morning or mid-day it'll be out.

...theyre a think tank, of course there biased. It says right on their Wikipedia page theyre known for their Conservative slant. Think tanks of any kind get little credibility in my mind because they just promote their ideaology.

Thats the world standard for temperature measurements :(.
I really hope they don't find a way to discontinue it.
So no more GISS climate data?

No. We are at near record highs. Europe is 26% down, we are nothing down. Our regulations are not tight by any measure. The technology is here, right now. Europe is an example. You can't just count on a bunch of technology magically showing up and getting implemented, you need policy support.
No. We are 2% of global emissions, therefore we can make 2% of the difference.
As pointed out before with sources, this "huge cost" is a myth.

So why does every other country have this responsibility, but we are absolved?
Which countries in specific don't have to do anything? Everybody but the top 3? The top 5?
Are all 186 countries below us absolved us as well? Because if so, the worlds in trouble.

Really? Europe reduced by about 26% and counting. Thats pretty significant.
And I guess your right. If we wanted, we could sit back and let everyone else do the hard work (including China, that is entering a cap and trade program to reduce their emissions). We could make about a 2% difference, which isn't nothing.
(Except for local pollution, which will continue to cost our healthcare systems billions every year.)
But thats the thing about climate change. Everyone has to be on board. If everyone did what you're saying except China and India, the world would be doomed.
And you may not have noticed, but China's emissions [may already be peaking](https://mobile.nytimes.com/2016/04/04/world/asia/china-climate-change-peak-carbon-emissions.html) because they did something. If China can do something, why can't we?

Less health issues from pollution is good for the economy.
People dying from the effects of climate change is not good for the economy.
Storms and floods that damage property and disrupt business are not good for the economy.
This goes two ways.

This crippling economy is such a myth its not even funny. 30% of the world will be under a carbon tax/cap and trade soon, apparently all those economies are crippled.
Quote from [MIT Technology Review](https://www.technologyreview.com/s/602857/canada-moves-ahead-on-carbon-taxes-leaving-the-us-behind/): "Most academic studies find that British Columbia's tax is reducing carbon emissions by 5 to 15 percent **without hurting the economy**".
Or yeah, we'll just run with this sensationslist proposition that any action will cripple the economy.

I'm 20. Harper lost the young generation, I think aiming to get at least part of it back is essential to winning an election. I hate O'Leary, but he also understands that. Losing that demographic as badly as they did last time will never win them an election.
They measured policy support too. We ranked bottom there too. You don't need to "play" with the statistics, we're already at the bottom by every metric.

On the Climate Change Performance Index, Canada is almost dead last. Russia and Iran are ahead of us. We are 53 out of 59 countries.
Don't make the mistake of thinking that Canada is doing lots already, we aren't. We are doing almost NOTHING compared to any other democratic countries.
If you believe the actions under Harper were sufficient, then fine, you are entitled to that opinion. But understand that unless we do more, you are essentially saying "Doing nothing is fine".
Don't kid yourself and pretend we're doing lots already. We aren't.

We are the 8th largest emitter in the world, about 2% of emissions. That is not insignificant.
China is entering a cap and trade program next month. If they can do something, we can.
Its already proven successful and [not a job killer](http://www.economist.com/blogs/americasview/2014/07/british-columbias-carbon-tax).

EDIT: And I forgot! Those efficiency percentages!
Its the most conservative way of actually doing something.
Totally agree! Thanks for the answer Michael.

Doesn't it feel like your giving him absolutely no credit for anything? I think he's done alright so far.

Look, if any candidate honestly thinks they have a better solution because carbon taxes are equivalent to cancer, I'm all ears, honestly. But they don't. No one except Michael Chong has presented an even mildly serious solution. Really, they all want to do nothing. And to me, that's unacceptable.

They are universally called market-based solutions. That was the terminology used in the scientific study, and thats how the economists referred to them.
Its like you didn't even click on the link.
Regardless, arguing about definitions is useless.
Market based solutions referred to cap and trade and carbon taxes. The result is unchanged.

Maybe you disagree with that money being sent to developing countries, sure. But if all your doing is using that money, then basically we are continuing to do next to nothing (since that money was over 5 years).
We should also note Michael Chong never supported that, but he HAS said that a carbon tax is his replacement for existing measures because its the more efficient way of doing it. So you're still using an inefficient solution that will cause more damage, not less, and will not do any more good for the world as a whole.

Great...wait a second. Investing in clean tech takes money. Okay so taxes go up or other services go down, oh WAIT that costs Canadians too. Carbon taxes still incentivize investment in clean tech, just in a different way.
Market-based solutions have near [universal support from economists](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/climate-consensus-97-per-cent/2016/jan/04/consensus-of-economists-cut-carbon-pollution). They are the most efficient way to do it. This is not pretending.

Fine, whats your much better solution that doesn't cost Canadians? (And we'll even forget about the whole "revenue neutral" part thats to pesky).
They do make an impact, [that is VERY well established](http://www.economist.com/blogs/americasview/2014/07/british-columbias-carbon-tax). Don't erroneously claim something doesn't work just cause you don't like it.
It was. Legally, the matter is settled. Going on about it in election time is vote pandering, the legal precedents are set.
China and all of Europe has done this. For some reason, Canada is the exception apparently where this is not feasible.

Supporting action on climate change is not a left wing action in most countries. Canada is the exception.
A revenue neutral carbon tax is the most conservative way to handle it

Lol the Reb is a special kind of terrible.

You're wrong on a few counts.
No, the Liberals did not promise it would pay for their social programs. Trudeau said the money would be returned to the province it came from, it was the provincial governments choice to spend the money or return it in tax breaks. The money was never the federal governments to begin with.
And Chong's idea is quite well tested worldwide. Tax cuts lessen as tax revenues drop, naturally. Or, the tax rises further. He plans a rising revenue-neutral carbon tax to account for less emissions.
Even within Canada, it is very well established academically carbon taxes do [reduce emissions](http://www.economist.com/blogs/americasview/2014/07/british-columbias-carbon-tax). I don't see any reason to be skeptical of that anymore.
It's also taxing all emitting activities, so I guess I don't see the morality issue. It's no more immoral than regulating energy production, which has the same consequences, if not worse. So basically, you're left with "If you try to do anything to combat climate change, it's immoral because it may adveresely impact some areas" (although it also benefits others) because if you're opposed to regulatory and market-based solutions, there is nothing left.
Yeah, the Globe and Mail is pretty good normally!

He may claim to be non-partisan, but I personally found he has strongly Conservative leanings. Even the sources he cited left me unimpressed (he was citing heavy pro-prohibition interest groups for Colorado analysis, but didn't even mention who it was from in the the article). I just don't have a lot of respect for journalists that can't even bother to cite from respected sources that at least attempt to be neutral.
With that being said, I'll give those blog posts a shot to see if I was too quick to judge!
EDIT: I don't mean Conservative party neccesarily, just right-leaning.

WRITING.TITLE: Best Way To Finance My Solar Farm Project?
WRITING.TEXT:
So I'm looking for some advice!
I have an opportunity to start a small solar farm. To build this will take $250,000 to $275,000 CAD (still working out the final details, but I think I can do it for $250k).
So my own money can contribute $30,000 about. That still leaves me very short. So I'm going to need to fund the rest of this somehow.
So here is the situation:
-My credit is good, but I'm also only 20 so it's limited. -Being a solar farm, it is one of the safer businesses out there. Power Purchase Agreement is already in place before construction breaks, so that's not an issue. Of course it's not risk-free, but it's a lot more certain than many new businesses.
In a way, I almost think it's like a rental property business. Relatively stable cash flow, and there is an asset at the core. Sadly, they probably won't be giving me a mortgage for a solar farm.
Ideally, I would like a line of credit secured by the solar farm. This would allow me to pay off more in the summer when it's producing more and less in the winter. However, I'm aware this probably isn't a possibility. If anyone has experience here, would a line of credit be possible at all?
So what are my options? I know private investors are a possibility, but do I have any other options?
Any and all advice is appreciated :)
TL;DR: Building a solar farm. How should I fund this?
